results.title: Highlands of New Guinea
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Social and economic changes in the Western Highlands of Papua New Guinea as demonstrated in the construction of an airstrip at Lake Kopiagu and the first Mount Hagen Show. Credits include Stanley Hawes, Frank Bagnall, Maslyn William, Shan Benson, Dennis Hill and Robert Gibbs.

results.title: Highland winter
results.creator_credit: Wilderness Society, Kath Scholes, Nick Housego and Roger Scholes
results.brief_description: An elderly woman living in a nursing home recalls images of the wild and isolated land she is no longer able to visit. The film recalls the winter journeys of her childhood in the Central Highlands of Tasmania. With Emily Talbot Higgins.

results.title: Highheels = High heels = Tacones lejanos
results.creator_credit: CiBy 2000, El Deseo S. A., Studio Canal+, TF1 Films productions, Agustin Almodovar, Enrique Posner and Pedro Almodovar
results.brief_description: Victoria Abril plays Rebecca Giner, a woman abandoned by her mother fifteen years ago who takes up with her Mum’s former lover, Manuel. But Rebecca’s mother is also one of Spain’s biggest singing stars and when Manuel is murdered, mother and daughter need to reconcile in order to uncover the secret’s behind the dead man’s assassination. As in most of Almodovar’s exuberant comedies, “High heels” is a celebration of women: women as stars, as mothers, as daughters and even women as men. His highly camp but extremelly stylish and emotionally operatic films have been instrumental in transforming our understanding of contemporary Spanish culture. Alomodovar’s films stand opposed to the moralism and dour poverty of the Franco regime; he fills his urban chaotic landscapes with a rich assortment of pleasure-seeking junkies, drag queens and eccentrics. In Almodovar’s universe the only moral laws are to not judge, and to love. In “High heels” the dysfunctional relationship between Rebecca and her mother comes good once both of them give themselves over to the perverse delights of gender, social and class confusion. Abril’s costumes are by Chanel and the music score is by Ryuichi Sakamoto. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Highfire: plan for survival
results.creator_credit: William Brose Productions, William Brose and Bruce Kerner
results.brief_description: Fire in high-rise buildings is a possibility that cannot be overlooked. This film is designed for all levels of employees and management in multi-storey buildings, and is a motivational film, demanding the viewer’s response to their own fire safety program.

results.title: Higher than high
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Liz Meyers and Virginia Murray
results.brief_description: 2000 years after Icarus and 200 years since the first flight of an air balloon, a young man finds himself afloat in the atmosphere, sitting in an ordinary garden chair and boyed by a collection of weather balloons. This humurous and endearing Australian short recounts the true story of a man, living somewhere west of Shepparton, who after sinking a few drinks and smoking a few joints at a party, finds himself a passenger in a makeshift aircraft. Bizarre and entertaining, “Higher than High” also portrays the unique sounds and textures of Australian rural life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Liz Meyers and Virginia Murray

results.title: High voltage
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and SEC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
Building Victoria’s 500KV system: recounts the building of Victoria’s 500KV line for power transfer from the Yallourn Power Station to Melbourne. Shows planning and testing of towers, film of actual construction of line land clearing and excavation of sites for towers. The film describes some of the planning and construction of the 500KV line - designed to carry power from the future generating stations of the Latrobe Valley to the local centre in Melbourne. Shows rolling out and cutting of the power cabling, installation of equipment at Hazelwood Plant, preparation and countdown for energizing in June, 1970. Photography by Jim Hayes. “Along the power lines” (1962): dramatised account of the work of the mobile repair units of the SEC. Shows film of the irrigation reservoir at Eildon and pipelines at Kiewa, power lines crossing the Murray River Valley joining New South Wales with Victoria and the various parts involved in the process of electricity production from brown coal. Footage of the power plants and lines shows inside the control centre near Melbourne, with the technicians at work monitoring the load on supply. Photography by John Leake with aerial photography by Jim Hayes.

results.title: High temperature research
results.creator_credit: Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Centron Production
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
The procedures for producing and measuring temperatures in the region of 2000 degrees are shown. Also studies the bond strength of gaseous titanium monosulphide and shows how its gaseous molecules as well as gaseous titanium and sulphur atoms are produced by the vaporisation of the high melting crystalline titanium monosulphide at this temperature.

results.title: High steel
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs, ONF | NFB and Don Owen
results.brief_description: This film from the National Film Board of Canada profiles a Mohawk Indian from Kahnawake just outside of Montreal Canada, who is a steelworker, working on the construction of skyscrapers in Manhatten New York. The Mohawk Indians from Kahnawake are famous for erecting the steel frames of skyscrapers and it is a tradition, which goes back generations. Some truly death-defining footage is shown of the steelworkers up on top of buildings skillfully shifting metal beams into position. The Indians community life is also shown in Kahnawake as well as some stunning historical photographs of Indians working on the Quebec Bridge in 1907 which ended in disaster. A song ballad by Bruce Mackay called Mountains of Iron and Steel is effectively mixed through the film. Directed by Don Owen.
